intro: Anagallis caerulea var. parviflora, commonly known as the small-flowered blue-eyed weed, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with slender, branched stems. The plant produces small, blue or violet flowers with five petals, often clustered in loose racemes at the ends of the stems. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to lanceolate, and covered in fine hairs. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and other open habitats.
